eligibility_requirement: Open enrollment, but tribal scholarships require 25% Navajo blood quantum
tuition_notes: Same tuition for all students; very low cost
federal_funding: Tribal College and University (TCU) funding, BIA Higher Education Grant eligible
tribal_scholarships: Navajo Nation Financial Aid Office grants
notes: Largest tribal college in U.S. Focuses on Navajo language, culture, and sovereignty. Most students are Navajo Nation members.

eligibility_requirement: Must be enrolled member of federally recognized tribe with Certificate of Degree of Indian Blood (CDIB)
blood_quantum_required: Varies by tribe (must meet tribe's enrollment requirements)
tuition_notes: FREE tuition for all enrolled tribal members
federal_funding: Bureau of Indian Education (BIE) funded, BIA Higher Education Grant eligible
notes: Only federally chartered university for Native Americans. FREE tuition, housing, and meals. Must provide CDIB and tribal enrollment verification. Competitive admissions.

eligibility_requirement: Open enrollment, priority to tribal members
blood_quantum_required: Varies by tribe for tribal scholarships
accreditation: Northwest Commission on Colleges and Universities (NWCCU)
notes: Strong nursing and forestry programs. Serves Flathead Reservation and surrounding areas.

eligibility: Enrolled member of federally recognized tribe, demonstrate financial need, attend accredited college
blood_quantum_required: Must meet tribe's enrollment requirements (varies by tribe)
award_amount_notes: Varies by need and tribal allocation; supplements other aid (not full ride)
application_process: Apply through tribe's Higher Education office or BIA regional office
application_deadline: Varies by tribe (typically March-July for fall semester)
stacking_notes: Can combine with Pell Grant, tribal scholarships, institutional aid
documentation_required: CDIB (Certificate of Degree of Indian Blood)
notes: Funding is limited and varies by tribe. Apply early. Some tribes have their own higher education programs that are more generous than BIA grants.

administering_agency: Navajo Nation Office of Financial Aid
eligibility: 25% Navajo blood quantum, enrolled member of Navajo Nation, demonstrate financial need
award_amount_notes: Varies by need and GPA; higher awards for higher GPA
application_process: Apply through Navajo Nation Office of Financial Aid (online application)
application_deadline: June 30 for fall semester, November 30 for spring semester
stacking_notes: Can combine with Pell Grant, BIA grants, institutional aid. Total aid cannot exceed COA.
notes: Must maintain 2.0 GPA for renewal. Funding is competitive. Apply early as funds are limited.

eligibility: Enrolled member of Cherokee Nation (no blood quantum requirement), demonstrate financial need
blood_quantum_required: None (Cherokee Nation has no blood quantum requirement for enrollment)
award_amount_notes: Varies by need and academic performance
application_process: Apply through Cherokee Nation Education Services (online)
stacking_notes: Can combine with other aid sources
notes: Cherokee Nation is one of the largest tribes with generous education funding. No blood quantum requirement makes it accessible to more students.

eligibility: Enrolled member of federally recognized tribe or Alaska Native, attend tribal college or mainstream college
award_amount_notes: Varies by specific scholarship program; some are full-ride
application_process: Apply online through American Indian College Fund website
stacking_notes: Can combine with other scholarships and aid
notes: Offers 200+ scholarship programs. Some are tribal-specific, some are major-specific (STEM, business, etc.). Highly competitive.

description: Rules for combining tribal scholarships with federal, state, and institutional aid
general_rule: Tribal scholarships can be stacked with other aid sources, but total aid cannot exceed Cost of Attendance (COA)
federal_aid_stacking: Can combine with Pell Grant, federal loans, work-study
state_aid_stacking: Can combine with state grants (varies by state)
institutional_aid_stacking: Can combine with college scholarships and grants (check college policies)
over_award_policy: If total aid exceeds COA, college will reduce aid (typically reduces loans first, then work-study, then grants)
reporting_requirement: Must report tribal scholarships to college financial aid office
tax_implications: Tribal scholarships are generally tax-free if used for tuition, fees, books. Taxable if used for room/board.
notes: Always report tribal scholarships to avoid over-award. Colleges may reduce institutional aid if tribal scholarships cover full need.

policy: CDIB (Certificate of Degree of Indian Blood)
description: Federal document certifying blood quantum and tribal affiliation
purpose: Proves Native American ancestry and blood quantum for federal benefits and tribal enrollment
application_process: Apply through BIA regional office with birth certificates, tribal enrollment documents, family tree
notes: CDIB shows blood quantum but does NOT prove tribal enrollment. Must also have tribal enrollment card/citizenship card. Some tribes (like Cherokee Nation) don't require blood quantum for enrollment but BIA still issues CDIB.

description: Difference between tribal enrollment and blood quantum requirements
tribal_enrollment: Official membership in a federally recognized tribe; requirements vary by tribe
blood_quantum: Percentage of Native American ancestry; some tribes require minimum blood quantum for enrollment
examples: Cherokee Nation: no blood quantum required. Navajo Nation: 25% blood quantum required. Many tribes: 1/4 (25%) blood quantum required.
federal_recognition: Only federally recognized tribes are eligible for BIA grants and federal benefits (574 tribes as of 2025)
state_recognized_tribes: Some states recognize tribes that are not federally recognized; these tribes are NOT eligible for federal benefits
enrollment_process: Apply through tribe's enrollment office with birth certificates, CDIB, family documentation
notes: Tribal sovereignty means each tribe sets its own enrollment requirements. Federal benefits require enrollment in federally recognized tribe.
